But, as Donald Rumsfeld writes, he's never much of a handwringer, I don't spend a lot of time in recriminations, looking back or second-guessing decisions made in real time with imperfect information by myself or others. As seems typical of so much here, that's partially true; the author has no taste for self-criticism or second-guessing himself. Andy Burnham criticised the introduction of an English Baccalaureate of core subjects at GCSE. Mr Andy Burnham told him it had a "narrow selection" of subjects and children should be learning more vocational courses. Are you really saying to young people and employers today that dead languages are more important than business studies, engineering, ICT, music and RE?, he said.
